CatDescriptText: Miss Carol Stoddart, Clairton and Mr. Lieutenant Adams, foundry worker, North Side, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, August 12, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "What do you think about Negro political leadership at local and national levels?  Does it carry 'weight' among Negroes or white people or both?  Why?" Miss Carol Stoddart's answer reads: "...If the political leader is qualified and has the ability, I think his viewpoint will be very much respected among both races."  Mr. Lieutenant Adams' answer reads: "I think it helps a whole lot, because certainly the whites are not going to look out for Negroes like Negro leaders will."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Carol Stoddart wearing ribbed and polka dot dress, standing in front of Jenkins Arcade, Liberty Avenue, Downtown; Portrait of Lieutenant Adams wearing cap and light colored button down collared shirt with two breast pockets, standing in front of Jenkins Arcade, Liberty Avenue, Downtown
